reasoning: I examined the activation patterns across all examples, noting that strong activation peaks consistently appear at or near CRISPR (Clustered Regularly Interspaced Short Palindromic Repeats) elements. In examples with CRISPR repeat annotations (sections 2, 3, 7), the feature shows specific activation around these elements. Even in examples without explicit CRISPR annotations, the activation pattern and genomic context suggest the feature is detecting CRISPR-related sequence motifs or structural elements. The strongest activation peaks exhibit similar shapes across different genomes.
findings: The feature consistently activates at or adjacent to CRISPR repeat regions in bacterial genomes. In section_7, activation peaks appear near CRISPR spacers. In section_2 and section_3, there's direct activation at annotated CRISPR repeats. The activation pattern is characterized by sharp, strong spikes (3-4 units in amplitude), indicating high specificity for these elements. The feature appears particularly active in firmicutes (Limnochorda, Thermoanaerobacterium, Alicyclobacillus, etc.) and other bacteria, consistent with CRISPR systems being widespread in prokaryotes.
conclusion: This feature robustly detects CRISPR repeat sequences and related elements across diverse bacterial genomes.
title: CRISPR repeat sequence detector
description: This feature specifically detects CRISPR repeat sequences and associated elements in bacterial genomes. It shows highly specific activation directly at or adjacent to CRISPR repeats and spacers, with consistently strong signal peaks. The feature appears to recognize the characteristic palindromic structure or sequence motifs common to CRISPR repeats, which function in prokaryotic adaptive immunity systems. The detection pattern is remarkably consistent across multiple bacterial species, particularly in firmicutes, suggesting this feature captures fundamental sequence patterns conserved in CRISPR systems across different taxonomic groups. The high specificity indicates this feature would be valuable for identifying previously unannotated CRISPR elements in novel sequences.
